Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Halo Modeling Strikes Back: New Techniques to infer the Galaxy-Dark Matter Connection in the Presence of Environmental Effects
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the next decade, a number of innovative telescopic surveys will provide scientists with a wealth of precise data regarding galaxies and cosmology. This project aims to remove recently identified deficiencies in models of the relationship between galaxies and dark matter, necessary to interpret galaxy survey data. The researchers will develop, and make publicly available, an open-source software package that could be used to minimize systematic errors in interpreting galaxy data sets, leading to a better understanding of galaxy formation and evolution, and also paving the way for unbiased use of galaxy surveys in precision cosmology. Complementing this novel research program, this proposal includes contributions to K-12 science education, addressing the critical need for students to engage in STEM-related disciplines. At Yale, PI van den Bosch will develop a custom planetarium show for the Leitner Family Observatory and Planetarium on the topic of gravity, and tailored to 8th graders. At the University of Pittsburgh, PI Zentner will serve as an instructor in the Buhl Academy, a new program at the Carnegie Science Center Buhl Planetarium that pairs scientists with Pittsburgh area K-12 teachers.

Halo occupation modeling models the probabilistic relation between galaxies and dark matter halos and is the premier tool for interpreting the clustering of galaxies. A standard assumption made in all halo occupation studies is that the mass of a dark matter halo completely determines the properties of its resident galaxy population. Mounting observational evidence indicates that galaxy properties, in particular star formation rates, are correlated with halo properties other than mass, such as halo age or concentration. This "galaxy assembly bias" (GAB) is a significant source of systematic error, both in efforts to understand galaxy evolution and in the precision cosmology program. In order to ensure the unbiased interpretation of forthcoming data, this proposal aims to develop the next generation halo occupation models that properly account for GAB. The researchers will identify the optimal set of observational diagnostics that can be used to infer the presence and strength of GAB, develop open-source software that properly accounts for GAB, and explore methods to mitigate the impacts of GAB by using alternative definitions of halo mass. They will apply these newly developed techniques to extant galaxy survey data, and make predictions for forthcoming surveys such as DES, eBOSS, DESI, LSST, EUCLID, and WFIRST.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project has made important contributions to our understanding, awareness and treatment of galaxy assembly bias; the notion that galaxy properties are correlated with halo properties other than halo mass. Galaxy assembly bias (hereafter GAB) is typically ignored, i.e., it is de-facto assumed that galaxy properties only depend on halo mass. However, this could result in very significant, systematic errors in our inference on galaxy evolution and cosmology.

This research project developed a new, flexible class of models specifically designed to account for GAB. We have written a software module (called dHOD) for the publicly available  Python package Halotools (https://github.com/astropy/halotools). Applying dHOD to clustering data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), we identified GAB at statistically significant levels, demonstrating unequivocally that GAB has to be taken into account if one is to obtain unbiased results. We also demonstrated that the impact of GAB cannot be mitigated by choosing a suitable definition of halo mass. We subsequently identified count statistics (i.e., the statistics of the number of galaxies in certain volumes placed randomly throughout the Universe) as the optimal observable to constrain GAB, and are currently in the process of applying this method to existing data to better constrain the exact levels of GAB in the Universe.

An important application of GAB is in the precision-cosmology endeavor; i.e., the program to constrain cosmological parameters at percent-level precision. In the past, various studies had shown that the combination of galaxy clustering and galaxy-galaxy lensing yields constraints in clear tension with those obtained using cosmic microwave background data. One plausible explanation is that none of these studies had allowed for the possibility of GAB.  As part of this research project, we first confirmed this cosmological tension using an independent analysis of data from the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS). Subsequently, we demonstrated that it cannot be resolved simply by allowing for GAB; although non-zero GAB significantly reduces the tension, even the most extreme models cannot entirely solve it. Either our standard concordance cosmology is incorrect, or the clustering+lensing analysis still suffers from unknown systematics.  To further explore this, we developed a new method (Cosmological Evidence Modeling)  ideally suited to constrain cosmological parameters on non-linear scales. We expect this to become a standard method for analysizing large scale structure data in the years to come.

In order to further constrain GAB, it is prudent to have reliable methods to constrain the masses of dark matter halos. This can be done using the observed velocities of satellite galaxies. The faster they move, the more massive the halo in which they orbit. Although an old idea, this satellite kinematics has been severely underutilized since the advent of galaxy-galaxy lensing, mainly because previous analyses yielded results in tension with clustering and lensing. We have matured satellite kinematics into an unbiased, competitive probe of the galaxy-halo connection.  Using our new, improved method, we analyzed satellite kinematics in the SDSS, obtaining competitive constraints that, contrary to previous work, are in good agreement with those from clustering+lensing. This resolves a thorny discrepancy in our understanding of the galaxy-halo connection.

An often used method in analyzing galaxy redshift surveys is `subhalo abundance matching’  (SHAM), which populates dark matter halos and subhalos in numerical N-body simulations with mock galaxies. The resulting mock Universe can then be analyzed in the same was as the data. Any disagreement between mock and data either indicates that the method used to populate the halos (i.e., the halo occupation model) is incorrect, or that the cosmology assumed for the numerical simulation is in error. However, there is another option; the simulation might suffer from numerical artifacts. Indeed, we demonstrated that state-of-the-art N-body simulations suffer from significant, artificial subhalo disruption due to inadequate force softening and discreteness noise. This puts serious limitations on the reliability of dark matter substructure in simulations, and hence on the popular SHAM method. In order to make progress, we identified two criteria that can be used to assess whether individual subhalos in cosmological simulations are reliable or not, and we have run, and made publicly available, a large library of over 2000 idealized, high-resolution numerical simulations of the tidal evolution of dark matter subhalos (https://cosmo.oca.eu/dash). These can be used by researchers to calibrate (semi)-analytical models for subhalo evolution to complement simulation results.

This proposal resulted in 27 scientific papers in refereed journals, and two completed Yale PhD theses in astronomy. Both students, one of whom was fully funded by this proposal, have been awarded prestigious postdoctoral fellowships and are currently employed as postdoctoral research associates. This proposal also provided valuable training and research experience for two undergraduate students at Yale University. Finally, the results of this work have been presented at numerous national and international conferences, as well as at a number of outreach events in the New Haven area.
